description:
In Self and Other, Robert Rogers presents a powerful argument for the
adoption of a theory of object relations, combining the best features of
traditional psychoanalytic theory with contemporary views on attachment
behavior and intersubjectivity. Rogers discusses theory in relation both
to actual psychoanalytic case histories and imagined selves found in
literature, and provides a critical rereading of the case histories of
Freud, Winnicott, Lichtenstein, Sechehaye, and Bettelheim.

At once scientific and humanistic, Self and Other engagingly draws from
theoretical, clinical, and literary traditions. It will appeal to
psychoanalysts as well as to literary scholars interested in the
application of psychoanalysis to literature.
